text: Behold, as the eyes of servants look unto the hand of their masters, and as the eyes of a maiden unto the hand of her mistress; so our eyes wait upon the LORD our God, until that he have mercy upon us.
text_kjv: Behold, as the eyes of servants look unto the hand of their masters, and as the eyes of a maiden unto the hand of her mistress; so our eyes wait upon the LORD our God, until that he have mercy upon us.
text_niv: As the eyes of slaves look to the hand of their master,as the eyes of a maid look to the hand of her mistress,so our eyes look to the Lord our God,till he shows us his mercy.
text_esv: Behold, as the eyes of servants look to the hand of their master, as the eyes of a maidservant to the hand of her mistress, so our eyes look to the LORD our God, till he has mercy upon us.
text_nlt: We keep looking to the LORD our God for his mercy,just as servants keep their eyes on their master,as a slave girl watches her mistress for the slightest signal.
text_msg: Like servants, alert to their master's commands,like a maiden attending her lady,We're watching and waiting, holding our breath,awaiting your word of mercy.
text_nasb: Behold, as the eyes of servants [look] to the hand of their master, As the eyes of a maid to the hand of her mistress, So our eyes [look] to the LORD our God, Until He is gracious to us.
context: Psalm 123 is a short psalm of ascent, likely sung by pilgrims traveling to Jerusalem for religious festivals. Understanding the social structure of the ancient Near East illuminates verse 2. Servants (male slaves) and maidens (female slaves) occupied the lowest rung of the social ladder, wholly dependent on their masters and mistresses for provision, protection, and even their very lives. The 'hand' isn't merely a literal body part; it represents the authority and power of the master/mistress. The master's hand dispensed food, assigned tasks, offered protection from abuse by others, and ultimately determined the servant's fate. A servant’s livelihood depended on understanding their master’s desires and anticipating their needs. Maintaining eye contact signified attentiveness, respect, and a readiness to obey. Deviation from this posture could result in reprimand or even harsher punishment. Female servants, often tasked with more intimate domestic duties, developed a particularly keen sense of their mistresses' moods and intentions. The implication is absolute reliance and humble submission. Further, the psalm was likely written during a time of national distress, possibly oppression by foreign powers. This historical context underscores the psalmist’s appeal to God for mercy, reflecting Israel's vulnerable position and desperate need for divine intervention. This dependency, while seen in slave-master relationships, parallels Israel's complete dependence upon God for salvation and deliverance.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 123:2 emphasizes humanity’s utter dependence on God. Comparing the psalmist's (and by extension, Israel's) posture to that of servants looking to their masters reveals a profound understanding of divine sovereignty. God is not merely a helper; He is the ultimate authority and provider. The 'hand' of God represents His power, His grace, and His judgment. Waiting upon the Lord’s mercy is not a passive endeavor. It signifies active trust and unwavering hope. The psalmist isn't simply hoping; he is vigilantly watching, anticipating God’s intervention. This waiting is characterized by humility and submission, acknowledging that God’s timing and methods are beyond human comprehension. The verse also underscores the asymmetry of the relationship. God is the master, and we are His servants. This is not a partnership of equals, but a recognition of God's inherent superiority and our subordinate position. This dependence, however, is not a burden but a source of comfort and security. God’s mercy is the only reliable source of deliverance from the hardships and oppressions faced by the psalmist. By focusing on God’s mercy, the verse contrasts the hopelessness of the situation with the steadfast hope found in divine grace. It emphasizes that God is not indifferent to suffering but is compassionate and willing to act on behalf of those who trust in Him. The verse encourages a persistent and expectant faith, reminding believers that God is attentive to their needs and will respond in His perfect time.
application: Practically, Psalm 123:2 challenges modern believers to cultivate a posture of humble dependence on God in all aspects of life. In a culture that champions independence and self-reliance, this verse calls for a radical shift in perspective. We are encouraged to intentionally detach from the illusion of control and acknowledge our constant need for God's guidance and provision. This means actively seeking God's will through prayer, Scripture reading, and fellowship with other believers. Like servants watching their masters, we must be attentive to God's promptings and willing to obey His commands, even when they are difficult or inconvenient. This requires a daily commitment to surrender our plans and desires to God's sovereignty, trusting that He knows what is best for us. In practical terms, this could involve making prayer a priority each day, seeking God's wisdom before making major decisions, and relying on His strength to overcome challenges. It also means recognizing that our talents, resources, and opportunities are gifts from God to be used for His glory. Waiting on the Lord requires patience and perseverance. It means continuing to trust in God's faithfulness even when we don't see immediate results. We may face trials and disappointments, but we can be confident that God is working behind the scenes to accomplish His purposes. Furthermore, the imagery of the servant looking to their master’s hand can inform our approach to serving others. As Christ-followers, we should humbly offer our time, resources, and talents to meet the needs of those around us. This reflects the same spirit of service that Jesus modeled, who came not to be served, but to serve. Embracing this posture of dependence allows us to experience God's grace and power in new and profound ways.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I confess that I often struggle with pride and a desire for control. I try to navigate life in my own strength, forgetting that I am utterly dependent on You. Forgive me for my self-reliance. Teach me to fix my eyes on You, like a servant watching for your hand, ready to obey your will. Grant me the patience to wait on Your timing, trusting that You know what is best for me. Fill me with Your Spirit, that I may humbly serve You and others, reflecting Your love and grace to the world. Thank you for your unwavering mercy and compassion. In Jesus’ name, I pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: To 'wait upon the Lord' is not passive idleness but active expectancy. It involves persistent prayer, studying God's word, seeking His guidance, and aligning our lives with His will. It's trusting in His timing and remaining faithful even when we don't see immediate answers.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: What does it mean to 'wait upon the Lord'?

faqs.answer: Practically, this involves being attentive to the Holy Spirit's promptings, studying Scripture to understand God's character and commands, and seeking wise counsel from other believers. It means making prayer a consistent practice and seeking God's direction in all decisions.
faqs.question: Q2: How can I practically 'look unto the hand' of the Lord in my daily life?

faqs.answer: While the servant analogy highlights our dependence, it also underscores God's benevolent care. A good master provides for and protects their servants. Viewing God as a loving master is empowering because it assures us of His provision and guidance.
faqs.question: Q3: Doesn't comparing ourselves to servants seem demeaning? How is this empowering?

faqs.answer: The emphasis on 'mercy' highlights humanity's unworthiness and God's unmerited favor. We don't deserve God's help, yet He freely offers it out of His compassion and love. This underscores the grace at the heart of our relationship with Him.
faqs.question: Q4: What is the significance of the word 'mercy' in this verse?

faqs.answer: This verse encapsulates the Psalm's plea for divine intervention amidst adversity. It expresses the psalmist's unwavering hope in God's mercy despite their vulnerable situation. It's the core of their prayer for deliverance and restoration.
